attributes.title: Physical Stock Take
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • A physical stock-take of raw materials and finished product was conducted on 15th March 2025 to review the adequacy and effectiveness of existing stock controls.
  • We noted that there were stock items with variations as detailed below:
    • Polybags had a variance of +813 Pieces.
    • Finished product had a variance of -62 pieces
    • White flour had a variance of -9.9 Kgs
    • Wheat Bran had a variance of +6.701 Kgs
    • Utto had a variation of +2.294 Kgs/Litres while all other materials had negligible variances as illustrated below:
attributes.recommendation: • The branch management should ensure there are minimal to nil variations in stock items since there are weekly stock adjustments done for variations during operations’ stock takes.
attributes.effect: • Variances in stock items especially when there were weekly stock adjustments imply weak stock controls.
attributes.remediation_plan: • The branch management should ensure there are minimal to nil variations in stock items since there are weekly stock adjustments done for variations during operations’ stock takes.

value:
• There were remixes on the production for 14th March due to an oven changeover failure that led to a lower yield compared to the BOM in the system. There is also a yield difference in super nutri and Naivas brown between the system and actual mixing chart which often causes such bread variances.
  • For polybags, there are bundles that come with excess pieces once opened and this results in excess variance as noted. This is beyond our control.

• There were remixes on the production for 14th March due to an oven changeover failure that led to a lower yield compared to the BOM in the system. There is also a yield difference in supa-nutri and Naivas brown between the system and actual mixing chart which often causes bread variances.
  • For polybags, we will work on minimizing the variances where possible.

·       In the prior audit report dated 4th February 2025 stocks were as seen below:

  • Bread -35 pcs
  • Utto -1.3 Ltrs
  • Wheat Bran  +6.5 kgs  and
  • Polybags +1,168 pcs.
  • The rest of the stock items had minimal variances
Previous
• Variances in stock items especially when there were weekly stock adjustments imply weak stock controls.
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Bread  Weight
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • A spot check on the weights of bread produced at Kitengela branch was done on 17th March 2025 to ascertain if the branch was compliant with the Weights and Measures Act (Sale of Bread Rules) Legal Notice 94 of 1970.
  • We noted minor instances of non-compliance to the standard weights as detailed below:
attributes.recommendation: • The branch management to increase spot checks in the production area to ensure adherence to the required weight standards and weighing procedures.
attributes.effect:
Implication:

  • Presence of underweight bread, however minimal, implied lapses in adhering to the standard dough weights.
attributes.remediation_plan: • The branch management to increase spot checks in the production area to ensure adherence to the required weight standards and weighing procedures.

value: • We have tried to control our bread-weights, and we will keep monitoring to improve further and alleviate any underweight instances.
• We have tried to control our bread-weights, and we will keep monitoring to improve further and alleviate any underweight instances.
•  In the previous audit report, packed bread underweights were noted as follows; 400g - 16%, 400 Brown- and 600g-7%.
Previous
• Presence of underweight bread, however minimal, implied lapses in adhering to the standard dough weights.
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Bread Damages Analysis
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • We conducted a review of damages arising from production and markets for the period 20th February to 15th March 2025 to detect if the damage levels were within the set limits.
  • The findings were as follows:
  • We noted the following:
    • Production bread damages were 0.18% of the total production which was within the set standard of 0.2%.
    • Market damages  were 0.75% of the total sales which was above the 0.5% allowed limit and had a cost implication of KES 61,1051.56.
  • We further noted that there were 288 pcs of Supermarket damages/returns that were posted in the system but were not recorded in the manager’s book. This was therefore factored in the computation of the market damage levels below:
attributes.recommendation:
• Enhance controls with regards to supermarkets’ bread rotation and balances control to ensure the returns from expiries are minimized.
  • Accurate recording of all damages especially supermarket damages.
attributes.effect:
Implication:

  • The production damage levels were well controlled implying good quality bread produced.

  • The market damages exceeded the set damage limits implying inadequate and inefficient controls for controlling supermarkets’ bread rotation that resulted in high expired bread returns.
attributes.remediation_plan:
• Enhance controls with regards to supermarkets’ bread rotation and balances control to ensure the returns from expiries are minimized.
  • Accurate recording of all damages especially supermarket damages.

value:
• We had instances of the Finmark oven breakdown that contributed to the market damages. However, the major contributor to the high market damages was the expired bread returned from supermarkets.
  • The unrecorded supermarket damages were moulded loaves that could not be received into the branch due to risk of contaminating our crates used for fresh bread, therefore we had informed turn boys not to bring the loaves into the branch but going forward we will declare this in our records and place them in boxes to separate them before they are disposed.

•  We had instances of the Finmark oven breakdown that contributed to the market damages. However, the major contributor to the high market damages was the expired bread returned from supermarkets but we will follow up with the sales team to ensure balances control is attained so as to minimize damages.
  • The manager has been advised to separate the moulded expired bread from supermarkets and ensure they are recorded and signed off by me before disposal
• During the prior audit dated 4th February 2025, it was noted that production damages were 0.33% of the production and market damages stood at 0.78% of the total sales.
Previous

• The production damage levels were well controlled implying good quality bread produced.
  • The market damages exceeded the set damage limits implying inadequate and inefficient controls for controlling supermarkets’ bread rotation that resulted in high expired bread returns.
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Mixing Chart Analysis
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • We conducted an analysis of both the mixing chart and mixing chart summaries for the period 20th February to 15th March 2025 to determine if the raw materials’ consumption were as per the set BOM and if the set yield and quality standards were achieved for production.
  • The following was noted:
    • Average yield was 190.40 loaves per bag
    • Average production was 97.96 bags equivalent to 87% of the set target of 112 bags.
    • Utto units consumption to bags of flour ratio was 1:1 as per chart but as per system it was 0.994 units per bag (2,335.9/2350).
    • 2,466 cases of remixes were observed for the reviewed audit period as detailed in the table below:

 

 

 

 

 

 

  • We further reviewed the system mixing chart summary values versus physical summaries and noted the variations below for the period 20th February to 15th March 2025:
attributes.recommendation:
• The branch management to minimize remix cases by adhering to the set procedures.
  • Accurate posting of mixing chart records to be done.
attributes.effect:
• The high number of remixes imply lapses in following the set procedures in the production process.
  • The difference between physical and posted mixing chart summaries values for utto implied erroneous records/posting.
attributes.remediation_plan:
• The branch management to minimize remix cases by adhering to the set procedures.
  • Accurate posting of mixing chart records to be done.

value:
• Oven breakdowns resulted in the remixes noted.
  • The system BOM affected the Utto variance noted between the system and the chart.

• Oven breakdowns resulted in the remixes noted.
  • The system BOM affected the Utto variance noted between the system and the chart.

·       During the prior audit, the following were noted :

  •  Average yield  190.35

  •  Average production 91.45 bags.

  • 2,129 cases of remixes were noted.
Previous

• The high number of remixes imply lapses in following the set procedures in the production process.
  • The difference between physical and posted mixing chart summaries values for utto implied erroneous records/posting.
Operations/Production Department

Findings.

  • We also observed that there were no pending IOUs as at 17th March 2025.
attributes.effect: • Cash controls were adequate and efficient.

value: • We will maintain.

attributes.title: Debtors' Analysis
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • An analysis of the debt balances as at C.O.B 17/03/2025 (Exclusive of Institutions) was performed to identify any occurrences of bad debts or unresolved balances by route. The findings were as detailed below.
attributes.recommendation: •  Follow up on pending balances for clearance.
attributes.effect: • Debt balances were an indication of long outstanding debts that could potentially become bad debts.
attributes.remediation_plan: • Follow up to be done on pending balances for clearance.

value: • The debts have been communicated to the TSM Brian Omondi who is following up on this.

attributes.title: Production Efficiency
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • An analysis was conducted on the efficiency of labour allocated to the production section for the period 20th February to 15th March 2025.
  • We noted that the average production efficiency was at 4.34 bags per production worker which surpassed the set standard of 4.3.
  • The results were as detailed below:
attributes.recommendation: • Branch management to maintain optimal allocation of employees to the production section.
attributes.effect:
Implication:

  • The branch attained the set target implying optimal allocation of workers to the production section.

value: • We will maintain and improve further.
• We will maintain and improve further.
• The previous audit report dated 11th February 2025 indicated a production efficiency of 4.10 bags per production worker.
Previous
Controls effective.
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • An assessment was conducted on the utilization of packers in the slicing section to determine if optimality was attained based on the set Company standard of 97 crates per packer.
  • We noted that, for the period 20th February to 15th March 2025, the packing efficiency stood at 98.61 crates per packer, which surpassed the set standard as demonstrated below:
attributes.recommendation: • The branch management to maintain optimal allocation of packers based on the set standards.
attributes.effect: • The branch attained the set slicing efficiency implying optimal allocation of packers.

value: • We will maintain and improve further.
• We will maintain and improve further.
• The previous audit report dated 4th  February 2025 indicated a packing efficiency of 94.67 crates per packer.
Previous
• The branch attained the set slicing efficiency implying optimal allocation of packers.
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Vehicle Fuel Consumption Analysis
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • A review was conducted on the branch vehicles’ fuel consumption vis a vis the set standard consumption rate to determine if there was optimal utilization of fuel for the period 1st February to 17th March 2025.
  • We noted that two vehicles for routes K1 and Lukenya (KDQ 558Z & KCF 205S) had overconsumed cumulative fuel of 46.71 and 107.85 litres respectively.
  • All other route vehicles’ fuel consumptions were within the set standard as detailed in Appendix I below:
attributes.recommendation: • Institute adequate fuel management controls within the branch.
attributes.effect: • Excess fuel consumed amounting to 154.56 Litres was an indication of weakening of controls for fuel management at the branch.
attributes.remediation_plan: • Institute adequate fuel management controls within the branch.

value:
• For K1 route, the vehicle’s speedometer had an issue of not reflecting all kilometers covered and we had raised this issue to Mr. Salim.
  • The other vehicle for Lukenya, we have noted and raised a deduction to the driver as at today Ded. Number 56078.

• For K1 route, the vehicle’s speedometer had an issue of not reflecting all kilometers covered and we had raised this issue to Mr. Salim.
  • The other vehicle for Lukenya, we have noted and raised a deduction to the driver as at today Ded. Number 56078.
• During the previous audit dated 4th February 2025, it was noted that one vehicle had a faulty mileage and another  KCN 104M had an oil leakage.
Previous
• Excess fuel consumed amounting to 154.56 Litres was an indication of weakening of controls for fuel management at the branch.
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Crates Verification
attributes.description:
Findings           

  • A review of the crate balances at the branch was done on 17th March 2025 to establish assess the existence and effectiveness of crate stock movement controls at the branch.
  • We observed that crates had nil variance crates compared with both book/system records.
  • However, we noted that there were high route crate balances as detailed below:
attributes.recommendation: • The branch management to uphold the existing controls on crates movement and follow up on eliminating or reducing route crate balances.
attributes.effect: • The crates’ movement was well controlled, however, route balances on 5 routes implied potential risk of loss of crates if left unverified.
attributes.remediation_plan: • The branch management to uphold the existing controls on crates movement and follow up on eliminating or reducing route crate balances.

value:
•  We will maintain
  • K1, Airport and Supermarket route crate balances were for supermarkets and schools, which were often verified by the sales team. The Lukenya, Sultan and Minishop crate balances are pending recovery from employees who resigned/were terminated but their clearances are currently being processed. The TSM Brian Omondi is following up on this.

•  We will maintain
  • K1, Airport and Supermarket route crate balances were for supermarkets and schools, which were often verified by the sales team. The Lukenya, Sultan and Minishop crate balances are pending recovery from employees who resigned/were terminated but their clearances are currently being processed. The TSM Brian Omondi is following up on this.
Previous
None
• The crates’ movement was well controlled, however, route balances on 5 routes implied potential risk of loss of crates if left unverified.
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Damages sent to Ingredients' Balance Analysis
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • We conducted a verification of damage balances sent to ingredients as at 15th March 2025 morning to assess whether all the declared damages were physically available or sent to ingredients as per procedure.
  • We noted that for the period 20th February to 14th March 2025, damages had a variance of -111.70 Kgs equivalent to -279.25 Loaves as detailed below:
attributes.recommendation: • Enhance controls for damage balance management and maintenance of accurate figures in the branch book records.
attributes.remediation_plan: • Enhance controls for damage balance management and maintenance of accurate figures in the branch book records.

value: • The variance in damages sent arose from moulded bread from supermarkets amounting to 288 pieces that had been disposed but going forward we will record this and ensure its disposal is signed off by operations.
• The manager has been advised to separate the moulded expired bread from supermarkets and ensure they are recorded and signed off by me before disposal.
N/A
Previous
Inadequate controls.
Operations/Production Department
